findings.description: `gaugeManager` can be unset → multiple view functions may revert
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all the strict criteria for BONUS_VALID. It identifies a concrete exploit where view functions can revert if `gaugeManager` is unset, which can impact the functionality of the contract. It does not require a trusted role compromise, has no existing mitigation, is in scope, is not a design choice, and has material impact.

findings.description: `abi.decode(data, (uint24))` can revert even if the staticcall “succeeded”
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all the strict criteria for BONUS_VALID. It identifies a concrete exploit where `abi.decode` can revert even if the staticcall succeeded, which can impact the functionality of the contract. It does not require a trusted role compromise, has no existing mitigation, is in scope, is not a design choice, and has material impact.

findings.description: `collectAllProtocolFees()` is an unbounded loop + single-pool revert DoS
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all the strict criteria for BONUS_VALID. It identifies a concrete exploit where an unbounded loop can cause gas limit issues and a single-pool revert can cause DoS. It does not require a trusted role compromise, has no existing mitigation, is in scope, is not a design choice, and has material impact.
This finding does not meet the criteria for BONUS_VALID as it is more of an informational issue regarding consistency rather than a concrete exploit.

findings.description: Missing events / observability for protocol fee controls
findings.reasoning: This finding does not meet the criteria for BONUS_VALID as it is more of an informational issue regarding missing events rather than a concrete exploit.

findings.description: `getSwapFee()` fallback can return 0 if called on a non-pool / malicious pool
findings.reasoning: This finding meets all the strict criteria for BONUS_VALID. It identifies a concrete exploit where `getSwapFee()` can return 0 if called on a non-pool or malicious pool, which can impact the functionality of the contract. It does not require a trusted role compromise, has no existing mitigation, is in scope, is not a design choice, and has material impact.

findings.description: `createPool` front-running / “pool squatting” is possible (may be acceptable)
findings.reasoning: This finding does not meet the criteria for BONUS_VALID as it is a design choice regarding front-running and pool squatting.
This finding does not meet the criteria for BONUS_VALID as it is more of an informational issue regarding sanity checks rather than a concrete exploit.
This finding does not meet the criteria for BONUS_VALID as it is more of an informational issue regarding access control and governance rather than a concrete exploit.

target_assessment.type_match_reasoning: The target vulnerability was not mentioned in the analysis.

notes: The analysis provided several findings, but none of them matched the target vulnerability. Three findings were classified as BONUS_VALID as they met the strict criteria for valid vulnerabilities. The rest were either informational or design choices.
